During the early to mid-1990's Spike Lee was a director who could do no wrong in my eyes. His films were of a very high calibre and then he hit a dip in form, seemingly never recovering. This however, was a reminder of how good he can be.
 Based on the novel by David Benioff - who also wrote the screenplay, it tells the story of Monty Brogan (Edward Norton) a Manhattan drug dealer who has to confront the choices he has made in life on his last day before serving a seven-year prison sentence. He spends his last 24hours of freedom with his girlfriend Naturelle (Rosario Dawson) his father (Brian Cox) and his two best friends Frank (Barry Pepper) and Jake (Philip Seymour Hoffman), all the while determining who really sold him out.
 This is a Spike Lee "joint" I don't mind taking a hit off, at all. Filled with very intense and dramatic conversations and confrontations between the characters, delivered with superb performances. Norton and Hoffman have already cemented their reputations but Pepper is a highly under-rated actor that I predict will be winning awards very soon with the quality he consistantly delivers. It's a real joy to watch them bounce off each other, adding real gravitas to some well written dialogue. Lee's direction is also up close and personal, giving it a further sense of realism. The post 9/11 psyche of New Yorkers is a running theme throughout and even one scene has two characters overlooking ground-zero as they discuss the end of an era. Lee also explores the multi-cultural diversity of the city, like he has done previously in "Do The Right Thing" and "Jungle Fever", among others. The diversity is also played out in the three friends, with very different values. It's an ambitious film with nearly every other scene or character, subtly displaying metaphor for the fragile state of the city they inhabit.   
 Despite a running time that slightly overstays it's welcome, this is a highly charged and thought-provoking allegory of capitalist America and boasts three superlative, indefatigable performances from Norton, Pepper & Hoffman.

I'm not really sure how this got by me. I love Ed Norton, I love Philip Seymour Hoffman, I love Barry Pepper and I love New York.

For whatever the reason, I just missed it. Well, I'm really glad I finally got a chance to see it. It's easily one of the better films I've seen in a while.

I'm not a huge Spike Lee fan, but I loved Do the Right Thing and The Inside Man. I'm not sure if there is any other director whose love for his city is more apparent in their films than Spike Lee. He really does love New York and that love shines through in almost every frame of 25th Hour.

That being said, Lee uses the New York backdrop in a very subtle way. The film never turns into a love letter to NYC. Lee is also very classy with the way he deals with the aftermath of 9/11. 

The 25th Hour includes some solid acting performances from some of today's greatest actors including Ed Norton who plays Monty Brogan, a drug dealer who is about to go to prison.

The film follows Monty around town on the night before he goes to jail. He's accompanied by his friends played by Pepper and Hoffman.

The film is very much about making choices and how one bad decision can change your life forever. Monty has clearly made some bad choices that have landed him in the situation he is in. At the same time, Hoffman is battling with his feelings for his underage student. He's struggling with urges that he's not sure he can suppress. Making the wrong choice could land him in jail like his friend.

The 25th Hour is very much a character study. The plot isn't overly complex and the story doesn't progress like your typical Hollywood film.

All in all, the 25th Hour is a haunting portrayal of a broken man (and city) who is hours away from hitting rock bottom.

Fantastic film that ranks up alongside Do the Right Thing and Malcolm X as Spike Lee's best films. The way he uses the very recent 9/11 event as an undertone of the way the main character feels about the state that the city is in is magnificent. The f*** you monologue was just as brilliant as the similar scene from Lee's earlier Do the Right Thing. The film takes its time throughout its run time but there isn't a moment wasted in the film. Spike Lee is one of the few great directors around that uses very straightforward narratives and styles yet he puts his trademark touches. The gliding dolly shot as Philip Seyour Hoffman walks out of the club bathroom was an awesome shot. Like Do the Right Thing, there is no real plot in the typical sense. It's just a day in the life of a man, this man just happens to be a drug dealer going to prison for his sins. It is a movie that certainly reflects the whole New York state of mind. One of the best films of the last 10 years. 10/10

The 25th Hour follows a friendly drug dealer named Monty Brogan(Norton). Brogan is set up on a deal and is now sentenced to 7 years of prison. The film now follows Brogan and all of his activities for his day of freedom before jail...

The film's story had the slowest start to begin but once it picked up, it did a good job of keeping me watching. The story also had random sub plots that I felt weren't really needed but if you can bare with them, you'll enjoy the film. I also can understand what everyone means when they bring up Lee's constant unneeded subtle reminders of racism in his films. If you're willing to overlook that fact, the story is still quite an emotional ride and has some really memorable scenes. 

The idea of the film was great but sadly, the execution could have used work. Though not perfect, the script was still good. The film still manages to capture the raw emotions of a drug dealer who just wants out. The story is structured good enough to the point that you truly feel the walls of time closing in on you. You got front row seats to spend Monty's last day as a free man thanks to the script.

The film's camera work gets nothing but love. The angles definitely came in with the assist to help capture the raw emotions. Also, the film's character development was quite entertaining. The film gives you a proper introduction of each of Monty's loved ones but somewhat leaves me still feeling short handed on Monty.

The acting was great. Every film that Norton is in, he always pumps out a 200% performance so it's not a shock he's still a powerhouse of an actor. Another key player in the acting department was, Barry Pepper. His performance kept up with Norton's. You truly felt Pepper's remorse and anger for his friend going away. Though the rest of the supporting cast was great too, Pepper and Norton's performances left a huge shadow over everyone else for me.

Overall, The film takes fire for uneven pacing and not enough focusing on Monty and as we've all heard, Lee's usual preachy antics. Regardless, the film bounces back thanks to an astounding cast and their heartfelt performances.The film still finds a way of getting you emotionally attached and definitely shows that Spike Lee's still got some ideas in him. This deserves a watch at the least!!!

Monty Brogan (Edward Norton) is about to be sent to prison for peddling drugs, a fate he approaches with both terrible anxiety and a sense of self-resignation. To ease the pain, friends and family of Monty meet with him on his final day of freedom to ease his anguish. 

Alongside Monty's girlfriend Naturelle (Rosario Dawson), his friends Jacob (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Frank (Barry Pepper), and his father (Brian Cox) also turn out to support their soon-to-be-incarcerated comrade. The emotional interaction between Monty, Jacob, and Frank is powerful, but it's at its best when only Frank and Jacob are talking, pondering Monty's fate and what will become of themselves as well. Pepper (who probably took this role to prove he could still act after the bloated monstrosity that was "Battlefield: Earth") has never been better, and Hoffman lends sterling support to the duo's yin-yang. 

Though Norton achieves one of his own career highpoints thanks to a rage-filled monologue in a restaurant bathroom (echoing "Catcher in the Rye"), it can hardly compete with a superior speech from Cox about what his son could do to escape his fate. 

"25th Hour" is also one of the few films to use post-9/11 New York as a fairly effective metaphor for the scars of the protagonists. It's not always perfect, but it does lead to some interesting moments.

25th Hour, Great Movies
For myself, watching *25th Hour* was sort-of like taking a palm reading. Noticing one line, representative of a life-path, stretches out long and far, while another line branches off and stops short in the middle of your palm. You question which life path will you take, and which are you currently on now. Are you one the short one or the long one? You question the various choices and decisions that you made in the past, and which life-line have those choices and decisions ultimately lead you down. In a round-about way, the three characters in Spike Lee's 25th Hour are struggling with these same kind of questions. The film is essentially about three people struggling with the choices that they have made in their past, and the choices they are to make in the future and which path will it ultimately lead them down. Edward Norton stars as Monty Brogan, a man whose life decision, becoming a drug dealer, has left him facing a seven year prison term. It's the morning before, and Monty has twenty-five hours left to examine his life, bond with his closest friends, say goodbye to family, find a home for his dog, and figure out a way to survive in the joint. At one point, Monty's friend refers to his incarceration, as "...going to hell and never coming back," and the audience gets the feeling that it's not just a coy metaphor. If Monty does survive his "time", he will most assuredly not be the person they once knew when he gets out. Even though he has grown distant from them over the years, Monty chooses to spend his remaining hours with his closest friends from childhood, Jacob Elinsky (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Frank Slaughtery (Barry Pepper). Socially and economically, these are two of the most dissimilar people one is likely to see spending time together in a film. Their only real connection is the deeply entrenched devotion they feel to their friend. Jacob is a nerdy English teacher, whose gift for the language, has done little for his social skills. His self-doubt and shame for being born wealthy has left him single, lonely and in a thankless job. He desperately yearns for one of his students, a beautiful and precocious seventeen year old, Mary D'Annunzio (Anna Paquin), but is afraid to act on it, fearful that such a decision will lead to him being fired from his job, or even worse, arrested. Frank, on the other hand, is on the opposite end of the character spectrum, he's a good-looking, rich Wall Street trader, who, unlike, his nebbish friend, has never had a problem with the ladies. Also unlike Jacob, Frank is much more forthright in his feelings about life, and his friend's impending incarceration, "He profited from other's misery and he deserves what he gets," he tells Jacob. Norton's character also has a girlfriend, Naturelle, played by Rosario Dawson, whom he believes might have been the one who sold him out to the police. There's also his father, played by Brian Cox, a retired fireman who owns a bar on Staten Island which caters primarily to fire fighters. Each of these people, in their own way, blames them self for what is happening to Monty. The story propels forward when the three childhood friends gather in a nightclub, with Jacob's student, Mary, and Monty's girlfriend, Naturelle, tagging along. It is what happens in this club, on this night, that provides the core of the movie. The accusations that are made, the favor that is asked, the choices that are acted upon, and the truth that is revealed, will stay with these characters long after the 25th hour has widdled and gone away. Will these friends be willing to enact Doyle's Law, in a figurative sense, and save Monty Brogan, the symbolic beaten dog? 25th Hour is also memorable for grappling openly with the aftermath of September 11th. Lee skillfully immerses it into the subtext of the story. Referenced in pictures of fire fighters who lost their lives at the World Trade Center, which adorn the walls of the local sports bar and the uptown offices of the traders; to the mention of Bin Laden in a particularly biting commentary by Monty; to Frank Slaughtery's defiant refusal to move from his apartment, which sits overlooking the ruins of the Twin Towers. Director Spike Lee, never known for being subtle, thrusts these images, and his obvious anger about it, into the viewers lap and compels them to deal with it. Also memorable is the venomous diatribe by Norton into a bathroom mirror, where he verbally attacks every group in New York regardless of ethnicity, sexual preference or socioeconomic standing. Not even the church or JC himself, is safe from his tirade, which ends when Monty realizes the only person he has to blame for his predicament, is the one staring back at him in the mirror. The whole film plays in a subdued, almost depressing, tone. There are no laughs to be had, no falsely engineered moments where the characters break bread, and cry, and get all remorseful, none of that. We feel as Monty feels: perplexed, distressed, unsure of those things to come and angry for how he happened to arrive at this place, and moment, in his life, his last 25 hours.

One of the recurring themes in this film is how people will suffer the consequences for their mistakes - their greed, their lust, and their naivete.  We learn that in another life, Edward Norton's character capitalized on the misfortune of others, yet in the first scene he takes a risk just to save a dying dog's life.  I really liked how this movie didn't focus on redeeming oneself after a life of crime, but instead dealt with the acceptance of the grim reality that follows after being caught, especially because his character is a good person and has a kind heart; he just got too involved with the wrong people and didn't know when to quit.  The ending sequence is very cleverly done and further proves the point that there is no realistic way to run away from punishment.

And, of course, Edward Norton is brilliant as usual.  So it's a damn good movie.

The 25th Hour was well written, amazingly directed, brilliantly acted, and meaningful. There were moments where it dragged, and there were moments where I was blown out of my seat with the brilliance. Edward Norton's F-You Monologue was perfection! Overall a great movie, that has a good heart, not for everyone, but it was for me.

25th Hour is a powerful drama directed by the always brilliant Spike Lee and starring the great Edward Norton. It's a unique film in that plot is based around a drug dealer without ever showing the dead; instead it focuses entirely on the aftermath. Edward Norton plays the convicted dealer who has 25 hours left of freedom before he must go to jail and serve his term. He spends the ensuing 25 hours trying to sort out his life and get some sort of redemption before serving his time.

It's a powerful film, once scene particular has Norton saying a Monologue in front of a mirror about the state of New York and life that is a really great scene. The script is excellent, as is the great cast including Brian Cox and the underrated Barry Pepper. The pace can be a little slow at times but it's very much a thinking person?s drama with many subtle messages throughout. The ending is perfect and will leave you with a slight happy feeling.

25th Hour is an excellent film that should be seen by all.

A lot of people don't care to give Spike Lee a chance as a filmmaker, primarily because much of his political opinions, are admittedly nauseating and tiring and I am certain many people think this mentality will remain a strong part of his work.  What is interesting about Lee is how his films are really honest, and even at times sensitive films that happen to be filmed in a brutal manner.  The 25th Hour is about a morally devoid drug dealer Monty Brogan (Edward Norton in a great performance that looks effectively exhausted and weighed down by his own demons) who spends his last 24 hours among the people closest to him (most of whom he's been gradually pushing away) before he must serve a prison term for his actions.  Monty's journey in the film makes for a terrific story:  it is the tale of a man who must come to terms with his mistakes and who in the span of 24 hours must attempt to rekindle the human connections with those he blocked out or risk the possibility of feeling alone and isolated in his final moments before prison.  I like how smooth the film transitions the character:  in one of the best scenes of the film early on Monty is chastising Enron, police, and every other group he feels should be held responsible for their despicable actions, spitting scathing profane bile at each one of these institutions, feeling as if he is enlightened to their true lack of decency.  What is great about the scene is that whether Monty is correct or not about their guilt is irrelevant;  it instead is a brilliant depiction of how Monty is looking for any person or institution to place blame upon besides himself.  And at the start of the film Monty tries to hide behind anything he can to not really except responsibility or feel truly sorry for his behavior.  Yet as the movie progresses Monty has to become more and more aware of what his actions have done and the pain his imprisonment will ultimately cause those around him.  Spike is none as a director who incites unrest and is severely radical, which isn't necessarily untrue, but the truth is in some instances such as this one, he can also craft a harsh morality tale that is made stronger by its virtuoso filmmaking.

James Brogan: We'll drive. Keep driving. Head out to the middle of nowhere, take that road as far as it takes us. You've never been west of Philly, have ya? This is a beautiful country, Monty, it's beautiful out there, like a different world. Mountains, hills, cows, farms, and white churches. I drove out west with your mother one time, before you was born. Brooklyn to the Pacific in three days. Just enough money for gas, sandwiches, and coffee, but we made it. Every man, woman, and child alive should see the desert one time before they die. Nothin' at all for miles around. Nothin' but sand and rocks and cactus and blue sky. Not a soul in sight. No sirens. No car alarms. Nobody honkin' atcha. No madmen cursin' or pissin' in the streets. You find the silence out there, you find the peace. You can find God. So we drive west, keep driving till we find a nice little town. These towns out in the desert, you know why they got there? People wanted to get way from somewhere else. The desert's for startin' over. Find a bar and I'll buy us drinks. I haven't had a drink in two years, but I'll have one with you, one last whisky with my boy. Take our time with it, taste the barley, let it linger. And then I'll go. I'll tell you don't ever write me, don't ever visit, I'll tell you I believe in God's kingdom and I'll see you and your mother again, but not in this lifetime. You'll get a job somewhere, a job that pays cash, a boss who doesn't ask questions, and you make a new life and you never come back. Monty, people like you, it's a gift, you'll make friends wherever you go. You're going to work hard, you're going to keep your head down and your mouth shut. You're going to make yourself a new home out there. You're a New Yorker, that won't ever change. You got New York in your bones. Spend the rest of your life out west but you're still a New Yorker. You'll miss your friends, you'll miss your dog, but you're strong. You got your mother's backbone in you, you're strong like she was. You find the right people, and you get yourself papers, a driver's license. You forget your old life, you can't come back, you can't call, you can't write. You never look back. You make a new life for yourself and you live it, you hear me? You live your live the way it should have been. But maybe, this is dangerous, but maybe after a few years you send word to Naturelle. You get yourself a new family and you raise them right, you hear me? Give them a good life, Monty. Give them what they need. You have a son, maybe you name him James, it's a good strong name, and maybe one day years from now years after I'm dead and gone reunited with your dear ma, you gather your whole family around and tell them the truth, who you are, where you come from, you tell them the whole story. Then you ask them if they know how lucky there are to be there. It all came so close to never happening. This life came so close to never happening.

A great film with tremendous performances and a wonderful screenplay. Stellar looks at humanity, friendship, grudges and forgiveness. At first I was a little 'stunned' at how the twist turned out. And then I realized, wait a minute, this movie has no twist. It's not that kind of movie. And it isn't. This is a drama at the lowest form in terms of context. The situations and story the character's revolve around isn't necessarily cut out to be considered your typical drama film. Which is what makes this movie so different. Ed Norton I believe is at his best in this movie. He has such a tame, yet balled-up angry persona we can truly feel his emotions when he shares them in a 5 minute reflection. Norton's soliloquy consists mainly of "dissing" everyone in NYC. I don't know about you but that takes courage and balls. Courage to stand up to the filth he sees in NYC, and Balls to say it. There you'd probably have to give credits to the author and Spike Lee for showing it in such a powerful way.

This must be the strongest declaration of love to the city of New York ever filmed. Following Edward Norton's drug dealing character through the final hours before he goes to jail, we follow him and his closest friends as he says his goodbyes, makes his preparations and comes to terms with himself and his life.

The movie has several fantastic scenes in it: The Fuck You-scene, Pepper and Hoffman overlooking Ground Zero, the trading room with Barry Pepper, how Norton and his girlfriend played by Rosario Dawson met, and the final five minutes of the movie flawlessly told by Brian Cox.

The acting is top notch. Edward Norton is perfectly cast, and Barry Pepper manages to more than hold his own against Academy Award winning Philip Seymour Hoffman.

Anyone having ever been touched by the city of New York should see this movie, and if you haven't been you will have to go after seeing this.

Very powerful film, with a protagonist brave enough to show post 9/11 state of mind, brilliantly filmed and displayed in the "F**k you" sequence, though it really wasn't about  a wounded man shouting his anger to the world, but merely an outlet for him(Edward Norton) to blame someone for his hard predicament. "25th Hour" does not just show an impending jail time for a convicted felon, but also shows how many things can drastically change in a span of a single day. Though the film contains many emotionally disquieting moments, the one scene I particularly admire because of its honesty is the exchange between Frank(Barry Pepper) and Jacob(Philip Seymour Hoffman) on how, after that very night, everything will never be the same again, how they could not invite Monty for a drink and reminisce of better times. "25th Hour" is not a film that carries out the nature of guilt, but it is about regret, of what could have been a better life.

Viewing back at Spike Lee's "25th Hour" is one of his best made films. "25th Hour" came out a year later in 2002 when much of America was still grieving after the terrorist attacks of Sept 11 2001. Spike Lee loves New York. It's in his bones and "25th Hour" is no exception. This film is probaly one of his most personal pictures he has made. The directing, writing, cinematography, the use of camera angles and movements, to the cast, and polished editing is first rate. 

The story: It is Monty Brogan's (Edward Norton) last day of freedom before he begins serving a 7 year long sentence for dealing drugs. He plans to spend his last night of freedom at a club with his childhood friends Jacob Elinsky (Philip Seymour Hoffman) and Frank Slaughtery (Barry Pepper), his girlfriend Naturelle (Rosario Dawson), and his father, James (Brian Cox). Frank, his best friend since they were both three, is an investment banker on Wall Street. Jacob is a quiet, dorky high school teacher who comes from a privileged background.

Monty sells drugs for a Russian mobster (What is it with me and Russian mobsters lately?), along with his partner Kostya. Kostya tells Monty it might have been Naturelle, who lives with Monty and knows where he hid his drugs and money, who tipped the cops. At multiple viewings I did not understand what these characters were up against and the personal sins they had to reedeem. The plot of "25th Hour" kinda reminds me of Clint Eastwood's great film "Mystic River" or maybe not. 

Personally I did not having any feelings for the Ed Norton character due to the fact that he was selling drugs and living very rich from those who suffered or even died from his strong naracotics. Yet by watching this again Norton's character clearly knows the situations he is up against, is a good guy but should have gotten out sooner. The last scenes of the picture is very important because it is Lee's way of displaying instant pennance to a drug dealer who basically sinned. 

"25th Hour" is a strong, passionate film about the choices people make and the dire consequences they will sadly regret. America is paying the price thanks to Sept 11 (which this story is set) is also no exception. This is a great picure.

P.S. - Special notice to Rosario Dawson's performance as Monty Brogan's girlfriend Naturalle. It is one of her best performance and reminiscent to another great performance she portrayed of Ray Allen's girlfriend in Lee's "He Got Game".

Uncompromising storytelling, as only Spike Lee (Inside Man) can offer. '25th Hour' is a grandiose, visually stunning, sucker punch of character study and statement. It's impressive that such an ambitious picture succeeds in everything it sets out to do. Set in 2002 in New York City, 25th Hour also address' post 9/11 anxieties, emoting the mourning of a city that has seemingly lost its soul, albeit, briefly. '25th Hour' is a masterpiece of storytelling, and will likely enrapture you from its first frame to its last.  
Highly recommended.

The 25th Hour is a genuine movie. It is very well acted and has an original story. There are few movies that I can remember that follow a character on his last day to live, but this story has a different outcome...prison.  What does it feel like to know that you have to go away to prison tomorrow? What goes through your mind?  Spike Lee explores that great question in the 25th Hour.

Edward Norton plays the part to a "T." A truly great actor that can really sink deep into his roles.  Extremely entertaining throughout.  This is also one of, if not the first movie to be shot in NYC right after 9/11.  Spike Lee adds that in and it plays a part in the feelings of Monte. The theme of reflection is brought to the surface throughout the whole movie. It's a movie that makes you think before you act and who your real friends are.

10/10 - It's been a while since I have been so deeply affected by a film as I was tonight. There's something about films that take place in the space of a 24 hour time period that connect with me on an emotional level; maybe it's the aspect of how short 24 hours can be, yet so important. Usually in these movies, there is hope in the end, and the protagonist walks away, maybe on a hangover, into the bluish haze of the dawn to a new day, a better future. In Marty's (Edward Norton) case, when the sun rises, his life is over for seven years. 

When you have one night to spend before you go to prison, how will you spend it? The film makes it clear through dialogue that Marty isn't exactly prison material, and he may be better off ending his life before it turns into a living hell. There is no grand, daring getaway where Marty defeats the system and drives off into the sunset, only dreams or the illusion of dreams and the quiet words of friends who are close to him. Seven years is a long time, longer than I care to imagine.

Spike Lee does his usual thing here: You know, the floating shots and whatnot. His style doesn't hinder the effectiveness of Marty's final hours though, rather, it helps accentuate the side story, that of New York post 9-11. In the film's most avant garde and profane scene, Marty's mind begins to rant and cuss out all who inhabit New York and what it stands for, from Puerto Ricans to Osama Bin Laden to Jesus Christ himself. His city is what he loves, and in that moment he has to tear it apart and burn it to the ground. His life is nearing its end for a while, just as New York is starting over.

The 25th hour is a great film.
Great acting and directing. Didn't quite grab me enough for an 8+, so saying 7.7. Many great quotes but favourite is the toast, 'champagne for my real friends and real pain for my sham friends'.
